    "patch": "@@ -1,60 +1,64 @@\n ---\n title: Troubleshoot Conditional Access policy changes\n-description: Diagnose changes to Conditional Access policy with the Microsoft Entra audit logs.\n+description: Learn how to use Microsoft Entra audit logs to identify and troubleshoot Conditional Access policy modifications in your environment.\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: conditional-access\n ms.topic: troubleshooting\n-ms.date: 08/13/2024\n+ms.date: 09/02/2025\n ms.author: joflore\n author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n manager: dougeby\n ms.reviewer: calebb, martinco\n-ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n+ms.custom:\n+  - sfi-image-nochange\n+  - ai-gen-docs-bap\n+  - ai-gen-description\n+  - ai-seo-date:09/02/2025\n ---\n # Use audit logs to troubleshoot Conditional Access policy changes\n \n The Microsoft Entra audit log is a valuable source of information when troubleshooting why and how Conditional Access policy changes happened in your environment.\n \n-Audit log data is only kept for 30 days by default, which might not be long enough for every organization. Organizations can store data for longer periods by changing diagnostic settings in Microsoft Entra ID to:\n+Audit log data is kept for 30 days by default, which might not be enough for every organization. Organizations can store data longer by changing diagnostic settings in Microsoft Entra ID to:\n \n - Send data to a Log Analytics workspace\n - Archive data to a storage account\n - Stream data to Event Hubs\n - Send data to a partner solution\n \n-Find these options under **Entra ID** > **Monitoring & health** > **Diagnostic settings** > **Edit setting**. If you don't have a diagnostic setting, follow the instructions in the article [Create diagnostic settings to send platform logs and metrics to different destinations](/azure/azure-monitor/essentials/diagnostic-settings) to create one.\n+Find these options under **Entra ID** > **Monitoring & health** > **Diagnostic settings** > **Edit setting**. If you don't have a diagnostic setting, see [Create diagnostic settings to send platform logs and metrics to different destinations](/azure/azure-monitor/essentials/diagnostic-settings) for instructions to create one.\n \n ## Use the audit log\n \n 1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Reports Reader](../role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#reports-reader).\n 1. Browse to **Entra ID** > **Monitoring & health** > **Audit logs**.\n-1. Select the **Date** range you want to query.\n+1. Select the **Date** range to query.\n 1. From the **Service** filter, select **Conditional Access** and select the **Apply** button.\n \n-   The audit logs display all activities, by default. Open the **Activity** filter to narrow down the activities. For a full list of the audit log activities for Conditional Access, see the [Audit log activities](~/identity/monitoring-health/reference-audit-activities.md#conditional-access).\n+   By default, the audit logs display all activities. Use the **Activity** filter to narrow down the activities. For a full list of the audit log activities for Conditional Access, see the [Audit log activities](~/identity/monitoring-health/reference-audit-activities.md#conditional-access).\n \n-1. To view the details, select a row. The **Modified Properties** tab lists the modified JSON values for the selected audit activity.\n+1. Select a row to view the details. The **Modified Properties** tab lists the modified JSON values for the selected audit activity.\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/troubleshoot-policy-changes-audit-log/old-and-new-policy-properties.png\" alt-text=\"Audit log entry showing old and new JSON values for Conditional Access policy\" lightbox=\"media/troubleshoot-policy-changes-audit-log/old-and-new-policy-properties.png\":::\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/troubleshoot-policy-changes-audit-log/old-and-new-policy-properties.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of an audit log entry showing old and new JSON values for a Conditional Access policy.\" lightbox=\"media/troubleshoot-policy-changes-audit-log/old-and-new-policy-properties.png\":::\n \n ## Use Log Analytics\n \n-Log Analytics allows organizations to query data using built in queries or custom created Kusto queries, for more information, see [Get started with log queries in Azure Monitor](/azure/azure-monitor/logs/get-started-queries).\n+Log Analytics lets organizations query data using built-in queries or custom-created Kusto queries. For more information, see [Get started with log queries in Azure Monitor](/azure/azure-monitor/logs/get-started-queries).\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/troubleshoot-policy-changes-audit-log/log-analytics-new-old-value.png\" alt-text=\"Log Analytics query for updates to Conditional Access policies showing new and old value location\" lightbox=\"media/troubleshoot-policy-changes-audit-log/log-analytics-new-old-value.png\":::\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/troubleshoot-policy-changes-audit-log/log-analytics-new-old-value.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a Log Analytics query for updates to Conditional Access policies, showing the new and old value location.\" lightbox=\"media/troubleshoot-policy-changes-audit-log/log-analytics-new-old-value.png\":::\n \n-Once enabled find access to Log Analytics in the **Entra ID** > **Monitoring & health** > **Log Analytics**. The table of most interest to Conditional Access Administrators is **AuditLogs**.\n+After enabling it, find Log Analytics in **Entra ID** > **Monitoring & health** > **Log Analytics**. The table most relevant to Conditional Access administrators is **AuditLogs**.\n \n ```kusto\n AuditLogs \n | where OperationName == \"Update Conditional Access policy\"\n ```\n \n-Changes can be found under **TargetResources** > **modifiedProperties**.\n+Find changes under **TargetResources** > **modifiedProperties**.\n \n ## Reading the values\n \n-The old and new values from the audit log and Log Analytics are in JSON format. Compare the two values to see the changes to the policy.\n+The old and new values from the audit log and Log Analytics are in JSON format. Compare the two values to identify changes to the policy.\n \n Old policy example:\n \n@@ -181,9 +185,9 @@ Updated policy example:\n \n ```\n \n-In the previous example, the updated policy doesn't include terms of use in grant controls.\n+In the previous example, the updated policy doesn't include terms of use in the grant controls.\n \n ## Related content\n \n - [What is Microsoft Entra monitoring?](~/identity/monitoring-health/overview-monitoring-health.md)\n-- [Install and use the log analytics views for Microsoft Entra ID](/azure/azure-monitor/visualize/workbooks-view-designer-conversion-overview)\n+- Learn how to [install and use the log analytics views for Microsoft Entra ID](/azure/azure-monitor/visualize/workbooks-view-designer-conversion-overview)."

We recommend excluding the following accounts from your policies:\n \n-- **Emergency access** or **break-glass** accounts to prevent lockout due to policy misconfiguration. In the unlikely scenario all administrators are locked out, your emergency-access administrative account can be used to log in and take steps to recover access.\n+- **Emergency access** or **break-glass** accounts to prevent lockout due to policy misconfiguration. In the unlikely scenario where all administrators are locked out, your emergency access administrative account can be used to sign in and recover access.\n    - More information can be found in the article, [Manage emergency access accounts in Microsoft Entra ID](~/identity/role-based-access-control/security-emergency-access.md).\n-- **Service accounts** and **Service principals**, such as the Microsoft Entra Connect Sync Account. Service accounts are non-interactive accounts that aren't tied to any particular user. They're normally used by back-end services allowing programmatic access to applications, but are also used to sign in to systems for administrative purposes. Calls made by service principals won't be blocked by Conditional Access policies scoped to users. Use Conditional Access for workload identities to define policies targeting service principals.\n-   - If your organization has these accounts in use in scripts or code, consider replacing them with [managed identities](~/identity/managed-identities-azure-resources/overview.md).\n+- **Service accounts** and **Service principals**, such as the Microsoft Entra Connect Sync Account. Service accounts are noninteractive accounts that aren't tied to any specific user. They're typically used by backend services to allow programmatic access to applications, but they're also used to sign in to systems for administrative purposes. Calls made by service principals aren't blocked by Conditional Access policies scoped to users. Use Conditional Access for workload identities to define policies that target service principals.\n+   - If your organization uses these accounts in scripts or code, replace them with [managed identities](~/identity/managed-identities-azure-resources/overview.md)."

ai_summary.Response: This commit updates documentation for Microsoft Entra's Global Secure Access client and Conditional Access policies. Key changes include revisions to the Android client installation guide, providing updated deployment steps using app configuration policies, and minor updates to the iOS client installation documentation. Additionally, several Conditional Access articles have been refined to improve clarity and accuracy, including adjustments to date fields, wording, and minor content improvements across topics such as session lifetime, resilience defaults, and audit log troubleshooting.

  "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/79ecce164f9eccdb63e3b2aabb491ba9e7129e26/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fconcept-conditional-access-session.md",
  "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fconcept-conditional-access-session.md?ref=79ecce164f9eccdb63e3b2aabb491ba9e7129e26",
  "patch": "@@ -32,16 +32,11 @@ For a list of supported applications and how to configure policies, see the foll\n \n Conditional Access App Control uses a reverse proxy architecture and is uniquely integrated with Microsoft Entra Conditional Access. Microsoft Entra Conditional Access allows you to enforce access controls on your organization’s apps based on certain conditions. The conditions define what user or group of users, cloud apps, and locations and networks a Conditional Access policy applies to. After you determine the conditions, you can route users to [Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps](/defender-cloud-apps/what-is-defender-for-cloud-apps) where you can protect data with Conditional Access App Control by applying access and session controls.\n \n-Conditional Access App Control enables user app access and sessions to be monitored and controlled in real time based on access and session policies. Access and session policies are used within the Defender for Cloud Apps portal to refine filters and set actions to take. With the access and session policies, you can:\n+Conditional Access App Control enables user app access and sessions to be monitored and controlled in real time based on access and session policies. Access and session policies are used within the Defender for Cloud Apps portal to refine filters and set actions to take. \n \n-- Prevent data exfiltration: You can block the download, cut, copy, and print of sensitive documents on, for example, unmanaged devices.\n-- Protect on download: Instead of blocking the download of sensitive documents, you can require documents to be labeled and protected with Azure Information Protection. This action ensures the document is protected and user access is restricted in a potentially risky session.\n-- Prevent upload of unlabeled files: Before a sensitive file is uploaded, distributed, and used, it’s important to make sure that the file has the right label and protection. You can ensure that unlabeled files with sensitive content are blocked from being uploaded until the user classifies the content.\n-- Monitor user sessions for compliance (Preview): Risky users are monitored when they sign into apps and their actions are logged from within the session. You can investigate and analyze user behavior to understand where, and under what conditions, session policies should be applied in the future.\n-- Block access (Preview): You can granularly block access for specific apps and users depending on several risk factors. For example, you can block them if they're using client certificates as a form of device management.\n-- Block custom activities: Some apps have unique scenarios that carry risk, for example, sending messages with sensitive content in apps like Microsoft Teams or Slack. In these kinds of scenarios, you can scan messages for sensitive content and block them in real time.\n+This control can be enforced with Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps, where Admins can [Deploy Conditional Access App Control for featured apps](/defender-cloud-apps/proxy-deployment-aad) and [use Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps session policies](/defender-cloud-apps/session-policy-aad).\n \n-For more information, see the article [Deploy Conditional Access App Control for featured apps](/defender-cloud-apps/proxy-deployment-aad).\n+For Microsoft Edge for Business, this control can be enforced with [Microsoft Purview Data Loss Prevention](/purview/dlp-browser-dlp-learn), where Admins can [help prevent users from sharing sensitive info with Cloud Apps in Edge for Business](/purview/dlp-create-policy-prevent-cloud-sharing-from-edge-biz). The Conditional Access App Control **Custom** setting is required for apps included in these policies.\n \n ## Sign-in frequency\n "

ai_summary.Response: This commit refactors the documentation for Microsoft Entra Conditional Access session controls. It streamlines the explanation of how Conditional Access App Control works with Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps, focusing on the enforcement of access and session policies. The update also clarifies how to enable these controls for featured apps and introduces guidance on using Microsoft Purview Data Loss Prevention for Microsoft Edge for Business.

  {

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/7786e8e509545bb05a290503cbf894169391b894/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-install-android-client.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-install-android-client.md?ref=7786e8e509545bb05a290503cbf894169391b894",
    "patch": "@@ -3,132 +3,100 @@ title: The Global Secure Access Client for Android\n description: The Global Secure Access client secures network traffic at the end-user device. This article describes how to download and install the Android client app.\n ms.service: global-secure-access\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 02/25/2025\n+ms.date: 09/02/2025\n ms.author: jayrusso\n author: HULKsmashGithub\n manager: dougeby\n-ms.reviewer: dhruvinrshah\n+ms.reviewer: cagautham\n ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n # Customer intent: As an administrator, I want to set up and deploy the Global Secure Access mobile client for Android devices.\n ---\n # Global Secure Access client for Android\n \n The Global Secure Access client can be deployed to compliant Android devices using Microsoft Intune and Microsoft Defender for Endpoint on Android. The Android client is built into the Defender for Endpoint Android app, which streamlines how your end users connect to Global Secure Access. The Global Secure Access Android client makes it easier for your end users to connect to the resources they need without having to manually configure VPN settings on their devices.\n \n-This article explains the prerequisites and how to deploy the client onto Android devices.\n+This article explains how to deploy the Global Secure Access client onto Android devices.\n \n ## Prerequisites\n \n-- The product requires licensing. For details, see the licensing section of [What is Global Secure Access](overview-what-is-global-secure-access.md). If needed, you can [purchase licenses or get trial licenses](https://aka.ms/azureadlicense).\n-- You must enable at least one Global Secure Access [traffic forwarding profile](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n-- Device installation permissions on the device are required for installation.\n-- Android devices must be running Android 10.0 or later.\n-- Android devices must be Microsoft Entra registered devices.\n-  - Devices not managed by your organization must have the Microsoft Authenticator app must be installed.\n-  - Devices not managed through Intune must have the Company Portal app installed.\n-  - Device enrollment is required for Intune device compliance policies to be enforced.\n+- The product requires licensing. For details, see the licensing section of [What is Global Secure Access](overview-what-is-global-secure-access.md). If needed, [purchase licenses or get trial licenses](https://aka.ms/azureadlicense).\n+- Enable at least one Global Secure Access [traffic forwarding profile](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n+- You need device installation permissions to install the client.\n+- Android devices need to run Android 10.0 or later.\n+- Android devices need to be Microsoft Entra registered devices.\n+  - Devices not managed by your organization need to have the Microsoft Authenticator app installed.\n+  - Devices not managed through Intune need to have the Company Portal app installed.\n+  - Device enrollment is required to enforce Intune device compliance policies.\n \n ### Known limitations\n \n [!INCLUDE [known-limitations-include](../includes/known-limitations-include.md)]\n \n ## Supported scenarios\n \n-Global Secure Access client for Android supports deployment for the legacy Device Administrator and Android Enterprise scenarios. The following Android Enterprise scenarios are supported:\n+The Global Secure Access client for Android supports deployment in these Android Enterprise scenarios:\n \n-- Corporate-owned, fully managed user devices.\n-- Corporate-owned devices with a work profile.\n-- Personal devices with a work profile.\n+- Corporate-owned, fully managed user devices\n+- Corporate-owned devices with a work profile\n+- Personal devices with a work profile\n \n ### Non-Microsoft mobile device management\n \n-Non-Microsoft mobile device management (MDM) scenarios are also supported. In these scenarios, known as *Global Secure Access only mode*, you only need to enable a traffic forwarding profile and configure the app according to the vendor documentation.\n-\n-## Deploy Microsoft Defender for Endpoint Android\n-\n-There are several combinations of deployment modes and scenarios for using the Global Secure Access client for Android.\n-\n-Once you enable a traffic forwarding profile and configure your network, the Global Secure Access Android client appears in the Defender app automatically; however, the Global Secure Access client is disabled by default. Users can enable the client from the Defender app. The steps to enable the client are provided in the [Confirm Global Secure Access appears in Defender app](#confirm-global-secure-access-appears-in-defender-app) section.\n-\n-### [Device Administrator](#tab/device-administrator)\n-\n-This legacy enrollment mode allows you to deploy Defender for Endpoint on Android with Microsoft Intune Company Portal - Device Administrator enrolled devices.\n-\n-The high level process is as follows:\n-\n-1. Deploy Defender to Intune enrolled Android devices.\n-\n-1. [Enable at least one traffic forwarding profile](concept-traffic-forwarding.md) if Defender is already deployed.\n-\n-1. [Confirm Global Secure Access appears in the Defender app](#confirm-global-secure-access-appears-in-defender-app).\n-\n-The detailed process for deploying Defender is as follows:\n-\n-1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Intune admin center](https://intune.microsoft.com/) as an [Intune Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#intune-administrator).\n-1. Browse to **Apps** > **Android** > **Add** > **Android store app** > **Select**.\n-\n-    ![Screenshot of the add Android app store options.](media/how-to-install-android-client/intune-add-android-store-app.png)\n-\n-1. Provide a **Name**, **Description**, and **Publisher**.\n-1. Enter the URL in the **Appstore URL** field.\n-    - `https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.microsoft.scmx`\n-1. Leave all other fields as their default values and select **Next**.\n-\n-    ![Screenshot of the completed fields.](media/how-to-install-android-client/intune-add-defender-app-fields.png)\n-\n-1. In the **Required** section, select **Add group**, then select the groups to assign the app to and select **Next**.\n-    - The selected group should consist of your Intune enrolled users.\n-    - You can edit or add more groups later.\n-\n-    ![Screenshot of the add groups steps.](media/how-to-install-android-client/intune-add-group.png)\n-\n-1. On the **Review + create** tab, confirm the information is correct and select **Create**.\n-1. On the new app details page, select **Device install status** and confirm the app is installed.\n-\n-**Users need to enable the client in the Defender app. It's disabled by default.** Proceed to the next section to confirm the app is installed and for how to enable the client.\n-\n-### [Android Enterprise](#tab/android-enterprise)\n-\n-Follow these steps to add the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint app into your managed Google Play store.\n-\n-The high level process is as follows:\n-\n-1. Deploy Defender on Android Enterprise enrolled devices.\n-\n-1. [Enable at least one traffic forwarding profile](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n-\n-1. [Confirm Global Secure Access appears in the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint app](#confirm-global-secure-access-appears-in-defender-app).\n-\n-The detailed process for deploying to the Google Play store is as follows:\n-\n-1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Intune admin center](https://intune.microsoft.com/) as an [Intune Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#intune-administrator).\n-1. Browse to **Apps** > **Android** > **Add** > **Managed Google Play app** > **Select**.\n-\n-    ![Screenshot of the add Google Play app options.](media/how-to-install-android-client/intune-add-google-play-app.png)\n-\n-1. On the managed Google Play page, search for **Microsoft Defender** and select it from the search results.\n-1. On the details page for Microsoft Defender, select the **Select** button.\n-1. Select the **Sync** button in the upper-left corner. This step syncs Defender with your apps list.\n-\n-    ![Screenshot of the Defender app details, with the Sync button highlighted.](media/how-to-install-android-client/intune-sync-google-play.png)\n-\n-1. Select the **Refresh** button on the Android apps screen so Microsoft Defender for Endpoint appears in the list.\n-1. Select **Microsoft Defender** from the app list and browse to **Properties** > **Assignments** > **Edit**.\n-\n-    ![Screenshot of the Edit option for assigning groups.](media/how-to-install-android-client/intune-google-assignments-edit.png)\n-\n-1. In the **Required** section, select **Add group**, then select the groups to assign the app to and select **Next**.\n-1. Select **Review + save** and once the details are confirmed, select **Save**.\n-\n-    ![Screenshot of the Add group option.](media/how-to-install-android-client/intune-google-add-group.png)\n-\n-After you assign a group, the app is automatically installed in the *work profile* during the next sync of the device via the Company Portal app.\n-\n-**Users need to enable the client in the Defender app. It's disabled by default.** Proceed to the next section to confirm the app is installed and for how to enable the client.\n-\n----\n-\n-## Confirm Global Secure Access appears in Defender app\n+The Global Secure Access client also supports non-Microsoft mobile device management (MDM) scenarios. These scenarios, known as *Global Secure Access only mode*, require enabling a traffic forwarding profile and configuring the app based on the vendor documentation.\n+\n+## Deploy Microsoft Defender for Endpoint on Android\n+\n+To deploy Microsoft Defender for Endpoint on Android, create an MDM profile and configure Global Secure Access. \n+\n+1. In the [Microsoft Intune admin center](https://intune.microsoft.com/#home), go to **Apps** > **Android** > **Manage Apps** > **Configuration**. \n+1. Select **+ Create**, and then select **Managed devices**. The **Create app configuration policy** form opens.\n+1. On the **Basics** tab:\n+    1. Enter a **Name**.\n+    1. Set the **Platform** to **Android Enterprise**.\n+    1. Set the **Profile type** to **Fully Managed, Dedicated, and Corporate-Owned Work Profile Only**.\n+    1. Set the **Targeted app** to **Microsoft Defender**. \n+1. Select **Next**.\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-install-android-client/create-policy-basics.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Create app configuration policy on the Basics tab.\" lightbox=\"media/how-to-install-android-client/create-policy-basics-expanded.png\":::   \n+\n+1. On the **Settings** tab:\n+    1. Set **Configuration settings format** to **Use configuration designer**.\n+    1. Use the JSON editor to configure the disabled configuration keys:\n+        1. Select the **+ Add** button.\n+        1. In the search field, type `global` and select these configuration keys:\n+            - **Global Secure Access** (this key is required to enable Global Secure Access). \n+            - **GlobalSecureAccessPrivateChannel** (this optional key enables Global Secure Access Private channel). \n+        1. Set the appropriate values for each configuration key according to the following table: \n+ \n+        | Configuration key                | Value    | Details   |\n+        |----------------------------------|----------|-----------|\n+        | Global Secure Access             | No value | Global Secure Access isn't enabled and the tile isn't visible. |\n+        |                                  | 0        | Global Secure Access isn't enabled and the tile isn't visible. |\n+        |                                  | 1        | The tile is visible and defaults to false (disabled state). The user can enable or disable Global Secure Access using the toggle in the app. |\n+        |                                  | 2        | The tile is visible and defaults to true (enabled state). The user can override Global Secure Access. The user can enable or disable Global Secure Access using the toggle in the app. |\n+        |                                  | 3        | The tile is visible and defaults to true (enabled state). The user **can't** disable Global Secure Access. |\n+        | GlobalSecureAccessPrivateChannel | No value | Global Secure Access defaults to value 2 behavior. |\n+        |                                  | 0        | Private Access isn't enabled and the toggle option isn't visible to the user. |\n+        |                                  | 1        | The Private Access toggle is visible and defaults to the disabled state. The user can enable or disable Private Access. |\n+        |                                  | 2        | The Private Access toggle is visible and defaults to the disabled state. The user can enable or disable Private Access. |\n+        |                                  | 3        | The Private Access toggle is visible but grayed out, and defaults to the enabled state. The user **can't** disable Private Access. |\n+\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > The **GlobalSecureAccessPA** configuration key is no longer supported.   \n+\n+6. Select **Next**. \n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-install-android-client/create-policy-settings.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Create app configuration policy on the Settings tab.\" lightbox=\"media/how-to-install-android-client/create-policy-settings-expanded.png\":::   \n+\n+1. On the **Scope tags** tab, configure scope tags as needed and select **Next**.\n+1. On the **Assignments** tab, select **+ Add groups** to assign the configuration policy and enable Global Secure Access.\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-install-android-client/create-policy-assignments.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Create app configuration policy on the Assignments tab.\" lightbox=\"media/how-to-install-android-client/create-policy-assignments-expanded.png\":::   \n+\n+> [!TIP]\n+> To enable the policy for all but a few specific users, select **Add all devices** in the **Included groups** section. Then, add the users or groups to exclude in the **Excluded groups** section.\n+\n+9. Select **Next**.\n+1. Review the configuration summary and select **Create**. \n+\n+## Confirm Global Secure Access appears in the Defender app\n \n Because the Android client is integrated with Defender for Endpoint, it's helpful to understand the end user experience. The client appears in the Defender dashboard after onboarding to Global Secure Access. Onboarding happens by enabling a traffic forwarding profile.\n \n@@ -138,19 +106,19 @@ Because the Android client is integrated with Defender for Endpoint, it's helpfu\n \n ![Screenshot of the disabled Global Secure Access client.](media/how-to-install-android-client/defender-global-secure-access-disabled.png)\n \n-To view the details of the client, tap on the tile on the dashboard. When enabled and working properly, the client displays an \"Enabled\" message. The date and time for when the client connected to Global Secure Access also appears.\n+To view client details, tap the tile on the dashboard. When enabled and working properly, the client shows an \"Enabled\" message. It also shows the date and time when the client connected to Global Secure Access.\n \n ![Screenshot of the enabled Global Secure Access client.](media/how-to-install-android-client/defender-global-secure-access-enabled.png)\n \n-If the client is unable to connect, a toggle appears to disable the service. Users can come back later to try enabling the client.\n+If the client can't connect, a toggle appears to disable the service. Users can return later to enable the client.\n \n ![Screenshot of the Global Secure Access client that is unable to connect.](media/how-to-install-android-client/defender-global-secure-access-unable.png)\n \n ## Troubleshooting\n \n-The Global Secure Access tile doesn't appear after onboarding the tenant to the service. Restart the Defender app.\n+If the Global Secure Access tile doesn't appear after onboarding the tenant to the service, restart the Defender app.\n \n-When attempting to access a Private Access application, the connection might time out after a successful interactive sign-in. Reloading the application through a web browser refresh should resolve the issue.\n+When you try to access a Private Access application, the connection might time out after a successful interactive sign-in. Reload the application by refreshing the web browser.\n \n ## Related content\n - [About Microsoft Defender for Endpoint on Android](/microsoft-365/security/defender-endpoint/microsoft-defender-endpoint-android)"
  },

This VPN is not a regular VPN. Instead, it's a local/self-looping VPN.\n+> - The Global Secure Access client on iOS uses a VPN. This VPN isn't a regular VPN. Instead, it's a local/self-looping VPN.\n \n ## Prerequisites\n - To use the Global Secure Access iOS client, configure the iOS endpoint device as a Microsoft Entra registered device.\n@@ -92,8 +92,8 @@ select **Create**. After a few moments, the Defender for Endpoint app is created\n \n         |Key |Value |Details |\n         |---------|---------|---------|\n-        |EnableGSA |No value |Global Secure Access isn't enabled and tile isn't visible. |\n-        |  |0 | Global Secure Access in not enabled and tile isn't visible.|\n+        |EnableGSA |No value | Global Secure Access isn't enabled and the tile isn't visible. |\n+        |  |0 | Global Secure Access isn't enabled and the tile isn't visible.|\n         |  |1 | Global Secure Access tile is visible and defaults to disabled state. User can enable or disable using the toggle.|\n         |  |2 | Global Secure Access tile is visible and defaults to enabled state. User can enable or disable using the toggle from the app. |\n         |  |3 | Global Secure Access tile is visible and defaults to enabled state. User cannot disable Global Secure Access. |   \n@@ -103,10 +103,10 @@ select **Create**. After a few moments, the Defender for Endpoint app is created\n         |Key |Value |Details |\n         |---------|---------|---------|\n         |EnableGSAPrivateChannel |No value |Use the EnableGSA configured option. |\n-        |  |0 |Private Access is not enabled and toggle option not visible to user. |\n-        |  |1 |Private Access toggle is visible and defaults to disabled state. User can enable or disable. |\n-        |  |2 |Private Access toggle is visible and defaults to enabled state. User can enable or disable. |\n-        |  |3 |Private Access toggle is visible and greyed out and defaults to enable state. User **cannot** disable Private Access. |\n+        |  |0 |Private Access isn't enabled and the toggle option isn't visible to user. |\n+        |  |1 |The Private Access toggle is visible and defaults to disabled state. User can enable or disable. |\n+        |  |2 |The Private Access toggle is visible and defaults to enabled state. User can enable or disable. |\n+        |  |3 |The Private Access toggle is visible but grayed out, and defaults to enabled state. The user **can't** disable Private Access. |\n \n 1. Continue filling out the VPN form:  \n     - **Type of Automatic VPN**: On-demand VPN"

ai_summary.Response: The changes update the documentation for installing the Global Secure Access client on Android and iOS devices. For Android, the article has been restructured to focus on deploying the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint app via Intune and configuring Global Secure Access through app configuration policies. It also includes new screenshots for the configuration process. For iOS, minor wording adjustments have been made to improve clarity. Both articles have also had their `ms.date` and `ms.reviewer` fields updated.

{"role":"user","content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: {
  "sha": "49266ac23ff2b8ad34d60a6c757e77812ef5b78f",
  "filename": "docs/identity/conditional-access/concept-conditional-access-session.md",
  "status": "modified",
  "additions": 3,
  "deletions": 8,
  "changes": 11,
  "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/67e1391f41826d98e7f0b7ead0a5e43c44c6a1fc/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fconcept-conditional-access-session.md",
  "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/67e1391f41826d98e7f0b7ead0a5e43c44c6a1fc/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fconcept-conditional-access-session.md",
  "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fconcept-conditional-access-session.md?ref=67e1391f41826d98e7f0b7ead0a5e43c44c6a1fc",
  "patch": "@@ -32,16 +32,11 @@ For a list of supported applications and how to configure policies, see the foll\n \n Conditional Access App Control uses a reverse proxy architecture and is uniquely integrated with Microsoft Entra Conditional Access. Microsoft Entra Conditional Access allows you to enforce access controls on your organization’s apps based on certain conditions. The conditions define what user or group of users, cloud apps, and locations and networks a Conditional Access policy applies to. After you determine the conditions, you can route users to [Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps](/defender-cloud-apps/what-is-defender-for-cloud-apps) where you can protect data with Conditional Access App Control by applying access and session controls.\n \n-Conditional Access App Control enables user app access and sessions to be monitored and controlled in real time based on access and session policies. Access and session policies are used within the Defender for Cloud Apps portal to refine filters and set actions to take. With the access and session policies, you can:\n+Conditional Access App Control enables user app access and sessions to be monitored and controlled in real time based on access and session policies. Access and session policies are used within the Defender for Cloud Apps portal to refine filters and set actions to take. \n \n-- Prevent data exfiltration: You can block the download, cut, copy, and print of sensitive documents on, for example, unmanaged devices.\n-- Protect on download: Instead of blocking the download of sensitive documents, you can require documents to be labeled and protected with Azure Information Protection. This action ensures the document is protected and user access is restricted in a potentially risky session.\n-- Prevent upload of unlabeled files: Before a sensitive file is uploaded, distributed, and used, it’s important to make sure that the file has the right label and protection. You can ensure that unlabeled files with sensitive content are blocked from being uploaded until the user classifies the content.\n-- Monitor user sessions for compliance (Preview): Risky users are monitored when they sign into apps and their actions are logged from within the session. You can investigate and analyze user behavior to understand where, and under what conditions, session policies should be applied in the future.\n-- Block access (Preview): You can granularly block access for specific apps and users depending on several risk factors. For example, you can block them if they're using client certificates as a form of device management.\n-- Block custom activities: Some apps have unique scenarios that carry risk, for example, sending messages with sensitive content in apps like Microsoft Teams or Slack. In these kinds of scenarios, you can scan messages for sensitive content and block them in real time.\n+This control can be enforced with Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps, where Admins can [Deploy Conditional Access App Control for featured apps](/defender-cloud-apps/proxy-deployment-aad) and [use Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps session policies](/defender-cloud-apps/session-policy-aad).\n \n-For more information, see the article [Deploy Conditional Access App Control for featured apps](/defender-cloud-apps/proxy-deployment-aad).\n+For Microsoft Edge for Business, this control can be enforced with [Microsoft Purview Data Loss Prevention](/purview/dlp-browser-dlp-learn), where Admins can [help prevent users from sharing sensitive info with Cloud Apps in Edge for Business](/purview/dlp-create-policy-prevent-cloud-sharing-from-edge-biz). The Conditional Access App Control **Custom** setting is required for apps included in these policies.\n \n ## Sign-in frequency\n "
}. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response: This commit refactors the documentation for Conditional Access session controls. It removes a detailed list of actions that can be taken with Conditional Access App Control and instead directs readers to Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps for further guidance. The update also includes a new section on enforcing these controls with Microsoft Purview Data Loss Prevention for Microsoft Edge for Business.

ai_summary.Response: The commit includes several updates to Microsoft Entra ID documentation. Notably, a new feature for Lifecycle Workflows is announced, allowing for the configuration of access package assignments expiration. Additionally, numerous entries in the SaaS applications section have been modified, primarily to update author and reviewer details, indicating ongoing maintenance and corrections within the documentation.

  {

    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/4d12e1532ab70d4dec4ae12e2b28884d69ea60b9/docs%2Fidentity%2Fenterprise-apps%2Ftroubleshoot-password-based-sso.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/4d12e1532ab70d4dec4ae12e2b28884d69ea60b9/docs%2Fidentity%2Fenterprise-apps%2Ftroubleshoot-password-based-sso.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fenterprise-apps%2Ftroubleshoot-password-based-sso.md?ref=4d12e1532ab70d4dec4ae12e2b28884d69ea60b9",
    "patch": "@@ -1,13 +1,13 @@\n ---\n title: Troubleshoot password-based single sign-on\n-description: Troubleshoot issues with a Microsoft Entra app that's configured for password-based single sign-on.\n+description: Troubleshoot issues with a Microsoft Entra app configured for password-based single sign-on.\n author: omondiatieno\n manager: mwongerapk\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: enterprise-apps\n \n ms.topic: troubleshooting\n-ms.date: 09/07/2023\n+ms.date: 08/21/2025\n ms.author: jomondi\n ms.reviewer: alamaral\n ms.custom: enterprise-apps\n@@ -17,7 +17,7 @@ ms.custom: enterprise-apps\n \n # Troubleshoot password-based single sign-on\n \n-To use password-based single sign-on (SSO) in My Apps, the browser extension must be installed. The extension downloads automatically when you select an app that's configured for password-based SSO. To learn about using My Apps from an end-user perspective, see [My Apps portal help](https://support.microsoft.com/account-billing/sign-in-and-start-apps-from-the-my-apps-portal-2f3b1bae-0e5a-4a86-a33e-876fbd2a4510).\n+To use password-based single sign-on (SSO) in My Apps, the browser extension must be installed. The extension downloads automatically when you select an app configured for password-based SSO. To learn about using My Apps from an end-user perspective, see [My Apps portal help](https://support.microsoft.com/account-billing/sign-in-and-start-apps-from-the-my-apps-portal-2f3b1bae-0e5a-4a86-a33e-876fbd2a4510).\n \n ## My Apps browser extension not installed\n \n@@ -31,11 +31,11 @@ Make sure password-based single sign-on is configured. To learn more, see [Confi\n \n Make sure the user is assigned to the app. To learn more, see [Assign a user or group to an app](assign-user-or-group-access-portal.md).\n \n-## Credentials are filled in, but the extension does not submit them\n+## Credentials are filled in, but the extension doesn't submit them\n \n This problem typically happens if the application vendor has changed their sign-in page recently to add a field, changed an identifier used for detecting the username and password fields, or modified how the sign-in experience works for their application. Fortunately, in many instances, Microsoft can work with application vendors to rapidly resolve these issues.\n \n-While Microsoft has technologies to automatically detect when integrations break, it might not be possible to find the issues right away, or the issues take some time to fix. In the case when one of these integrations does not work correctly, open a support case so it can be fixed as quickly as possible.\n+While Microsoft has technologies to automatically detect when integrations break, it might not be possible to find the issues right away, or the issues take some time to fix. In the case when one of these integrations doesn't work correctly, open a support case so it can be fixed as quickly as possible.\n \n **If you are in contact with this application’s vendor,** send them our way so Microsoft can work with them to natively integrate their application with Microsoft Entra ID. You can send the vendor to the [Listing your application in the Microsoft Entra application gallery](~/identity/enterprise-apps/v2-howto-app-gallery-listing.md) to get them started.\n \n@@ -45,59 +45,37 @@ To resolve this issue, first try these things:\n \n - Have the user first try to **sign in to the application website directly** with the credentials stored for them.\n \n-  - If sign-in works, then have the user click the **Update credentials** button on the **Application Tile** in the **Apps** section of [My Apps](https://myapps.microsoft.com/) to update them to the latest known working username and password.\n+  - If sign-in works, then have the user select the **Update credentials** button on the **Application Tile** in the **Apps** section of [My Apps](https://myapps.microsoft.com/) to update them to the latest known working username and password.\n \n   - If you, or another administrator assigned the credentials for this user, find the user or group’s application assignment by navigating to the **Users & Groups** tab of the application, selecting the assignment and clicking the **Update Credentials** button.\n \n - If the user assigned their own credentials, have the user **check to be sure that their password has not expired in the application** and if so, **update their expired password** by signing in to the application directly.\n \n-  - After the password has been updated in the application, request the user to click the **Update credentials** button on the **Application Tile** in the **Apps** section of [My Apps](https://myapps.microsoft.com/) to update them to the latest known working username and password.\n+  - After the password has been updated in the application, request the user to select the **Update credentials** button on the **Application Tile** in the **Apps** section of [My Apps](https://myapps.microsoft.com/) to update them to the latest known working username and password.\n \n   - If you, or another administrator assigned the credentials for this user, find the user or group’s application assignment by navigating to the **Users & Groups** tab of the application, selecting the assignment and clicking the **Update Credentials** button.\n \n - Ensure that the My Apps browser extension is running and enabled in your user’s browser.\n \n-- Ensure that your users are not trying to sign in to the application from My Apps while in **incognito, inPrivate, or Private mode**. The My Apps extension is not supported in these modes.\n+- Ensure that your users aren't trying to sign in to the application from My Apps while in **incognito, inPrivate, or Private mode**. The My Apps extension isn't supported in these modes.\n \n-In case the previous suggestions do not work, it could be the case that a change has occurred on the application side that has temporarily broken the application’s integration with Microsoft Entra ID. For example, this can occur when the application vendor introduces a script on their page which behaves differently for manual vs automated input, which causes automated integration, like our own, to break. Fortunately, in many instances, Microsoft can work with application vendors to rapidly resolve these issues.\n+In case the previous suggestions don't work, it could be the case that a change has occurred on the application side that has temporarily broken the application’s integration with Microsoft Entra ID. For example, this can occur when the application vendor introduces a script on their page, which behaves differently for manual vs automated input, which causes automated integration, like our own, to break. Fortunately, in many instances, Microsoft can work with application vendors to rapidly resolve these issues.\n \n-While Microsoft has technologies to automatically detect when application integrations break, it might not be possible to find the issues right away, or the issues might take some time to fix. When an integration does not work correctly, you can open a support case to get it fixed as quickly as possible.\n+While Microsoft has technologies to automatically detect when application integrations break, it might not be possible to find the issues right away, or the issues might take some time to fix. When an integration doesn't work correctly, you can open a support case to get it fixed as quickly as possible.\n \n In addition to this, **if you are in contact with this application’s vendor,** **send them our way** so we can work with them to natively integrate their application with Microsoft Entra ID. You can send the vendor to the [Listing your application in the Microsoft Entra application gallery](~/identity/enterprise-apps/v2-howto-app-gallery-listing.md) to get them started.\n \n-## Check if the application’s login page has changed recently or requires an additional field\n+## Check if the application’s sign-in page has changed recently or requires an extra field\n \n-If the application’s login page has changed drastically, sometimes this causes our integrations to break. An example of this is when an application vendor adds a sign-in field, a captcha, or multi-factor authentication to their experiences. Fortunately, in many instances, Microsoft can work with application vendors to rapidly resolve these issues.\n+If the application’s sign-in page has changed drastically, sometimes this causes our integrations to break. An example of this is when an application vendor adds a sign-in field, a captcha, or multifactor authentication to their experiences. Fortunately, in many instances, Microsoft can work with application vendors to rapidly resolve these issues.\n \n-While Microsoft has technologies to automatically detect when application integrations break, it might not be possible to find the issues right away, or the issues might take some time to fix. When an integration does not work correctly, you can open a support case to get it fixed as quickly as possible.\n+While Microsoft has technologies to automatically detect when application integrations break, it might not be possible to find the issues right away, or the issues might take some time to fix. When an integration doesn't work correctly, you can open a support case to get it fixed as quickly as possible.\n \n In addition to this, **if you are in contact with this application’s vendor,** **send them our way** so we can work with them to natively integrate their application with Microsoft Entra ID. You can send the vendor to the [Listing your application in the Microsoft Entra application gallery](~/identity/enterprise-apps/v2-howto-app-gallery-listing.md) to get them started.\n \n ## Capture sign-in fields for an app\n \n-Sign-in field capture is supported only for HTML-enabled sign-in pages. It's not supported for non-standard sign-in pages, like those that use Adobe Flash or other non-HTML-enabled technologies.\n-\n-There are two ways to capture sign-in fields for your custom apps:\n-\n-- **Automatic sign-in field capture** works well with most HTML-enabled sign-in pages, *if they use well-known DIV IDs* for the user name and password fields. The HTML on the page is scraped to find DIV IDs that match certain criteria. That metadata is saved so that it can be replayed to the app later.\n-\n-- **Manual sign-in field capture** is used if the app vendor *doesn't label the sign-in input fields*. Manual capture is also used if the vendor *renders multiple fields that can't be auto-detected*. ai_summary.Response:
This commit updates documentation for Microsoft Entra ID enterprise applications.

Key changes include:

*   **Troubleshoot password-based SSO:** The document has been refined with clearer language and updated instructions for troubleshooting password-based single sign-on issues, including guidance on the My Apps browser extension and handling application sign-in page changes. Several minor grammatical and wording adjustments have been made throughout.
*   **Timetabling Solutions Tutorial:** The document has been updated to reflect a change in the terminology used for the Timetabling Solutions interface, from "Administration Console" to "Management Portal."

Existing installations will be auto-upgraded to this build starting September 4, 2025 and will be done in multiple phases. \n+\n+\n+### Added Features \n+\n+- Improved the setup process for Application-Based Authentication to handle TPM-backed certificates (certificates protected by a Trusted Platform Module, see [What is a TPM?](/windows/security/information-protection/tpm/trusted-platform-module-overview)). The system now tests a certificate’s signing capability upfront and automatically falls back to software-based certificates if TPM signature fails. \n+- Implemented automatic removal of certificates if an Application-Based Authentication configuration fails after a certificate is created. This prevents unused certificates from lingering on the server in failure scenarios, improving security by avoiding accumulation of orphaned certificates. \n+\n+### Bug fixes\n+\n+- Resolved an issue on FIPS-enabled servers that was causing setup failures. Application-Based Authentication now works correctly on servers with FIPS mode enabled by using FIPS-compliant cryptographic algorithms. \n+ > [!TIP]\n+ > FIPS (Federal Information Processing Standards) mode is a Windows security setting that enforces the use of cryptographic algorithms for sensitive data. When FIPS mode is enabled, only FIPS-compliant algorithms can be used, which is why this fix ensures compatibility for environments requiring strict security standards.\n+- Fixed an issue where certificate auto-rotation was incorrectly reported as active when the scheduler was suspended. The auto-rotation logic now checks the scheduler’s state before indicating status, ensuring the *View or export current configuration wizard* accurately reflects whether auto-rotation is enabled. \n+- Removed an inappropriate admin audit event that was being logged for automatic certificate operations. These background certificate actions no longer generate administrative audit log entries, resulting in a cleaner audit trail (only actual administrator-initiated changes will appear in the Entra Connect Sync audit logs). \n+\n ## 2.5.76.0\n \n ### Release status\n \n-07/31/2025: Released for download via the Microsoft Entra admin center. ai_summary.Response:
Here's a summary of the changes:

The documentation for direct federation has been updated to clarify the `AssertionConsumerService` value for external tenants, adding a note about configuring it on the external IdP. Additionally, a minor typo has been corrected in the React single-page app tutorial. Finally, the Microsoft Entra Connect version history has been updated with details for version 2.5.79.0, including new features related to application-based authentication and bug fixes, as well as a revised release date for version 2.5.76.0.

Specifically, the lifecycle workflow tasks section now reflects the ability to customise the "Remove all access package assignments for user" task to include a delay before removal. Additionally, the Privileged Identity Management (PIM) how-to guide for adding roles to users has been updated with a minor date change and a clarification regarding the assignment of custom roles with administrative unit scope.

ai_summary.Response: This commit updates the documentation for assigning roles in Privileged Identity Management. It modifies the `ms.date` metadata to August 29, 2025, and clarifies the process for assigning custom roles with administrative unit scope. The updated text explains that such assignments must be initiated from within the administrative unit itself, rather than the "Roles & admins" page, and provides a link to further information on managing roles with administrative unit scope.

Specifically, it enhances the description of the "Remove all access package assignments for user" task, informing users that they can now configure whether these assignments are removed immediately or after a specified number of days.     "patch": "@@ -7,47 +7,44 @@ manager: pmwongera\n ms.service: entra-id-governance\n ms.topic: how-to\n ms.subservice: privileged-identity-management\n-ms.date: 04/30/2025\n+ms.date: 08/26/2025\n ms.author: barclayn\n ms.reviewer: shaunliu\n ms.custom: pim\n ---\n # View audit history for Microsoft Entra roles in Privileged Identity Management\n \n-You can use the Microsoft Entra Privileged Identity Management (PIM) audit history to see all role assignments and activations within the past 30 days for all privileged roles. If you want to retain audit data for longer than the default retention period, you can use Azure Monitor to route it to an Azure storage account. For more information, see [Archive Microsoft Entra logs to an Azure storage account](~/identity/monitoring-health/howto-archive-logs-to-storage-account.md). If you want to see the full audit history of activity in your organization in Microsoft Entra ID including administrator, end user, and synchronization activity, you can use the [Microsoft Entra security and activity reports](~/identity/monitoring-health/overview-monitoring-health.md).\n+You can use the Microsoft Entra Privileged Identity Management (PIM) audit history to see role assignments changes and activations done through PIM. Data is available for the past 30 days. If you want to retain audit data for longer than the default retention period, you can use Azure Monitor to route it to an Azure storage account. For more information, see [Archive Microsoft Entra logs to an Azure storage account](~/identity/monitoring-health/howto-archive-logs-to-storage-account.md). To see full audit history of Microsoft Entra ID activity including administrator, end user, and synchronization activity, you can use the [Microsoft Entra security and activity reports](~/identity/monitoring-health/overview-monitoring-health.md).\n \n Follow these steps to view the audit history for Microsoft Entra roles.\n \n ## View resource audit history\n \n+Use **Resource audit** blade to view all activity associated with your Microsoft Entra role assignment and PIM Policy management in PIM.\n \n-Resource audit gives you a view of all activity associated with your Microsoft Entra roles.\n-\n-1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Privileged Role Administrator](~/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#privileged-role-administrator).\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as a Global Administrator, Global Reader, Privileged Role Administrator, Security Administrator, or Security Reader.\n \n 1. Browse to **ID Governance** > **Privileged Identity Management** > **Microsoft Entra roles**.\n \n 1. Select **Resource audit**.\n \n 1. Filter the history using a predefined date or custom range.\n \n-    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/azure-pim-resource-rbac/rbac-resource-audit.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Microsoft Entra role audit list with filters.\":::\n+    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/pim-how-use-audit-log/resource-audit.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Microsoft Entra role audit list with filters.\":::\n \n ## View my audit\n \n-My audit enables you to view your personal role activity.\n+Use **My audit** blade to view your role activity for Microsoft Entra role assignment and PIM Policy management.\n \n-1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Privileged Role Administrator](~/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#privileged-role-administrator).\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com).\n \n 1. Browse to **ID Governance** > **Privileged Identity Management** > **Microsoft Entra roles**.\n \n-1. Select the resource you want to view audit history for.\n-\n 1. Select **My audit**.\n \n 1. Filter the history using a predefined date or custom range.\n \n-    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/azure-pim-resource-rbac/my-audit-time.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Audit list page for the current user.\":::\n+    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/pim-how-use-audit-log/my-audit.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Audit list page for the current user.\":::\n \n ## Next steps\n "

    "patch": "@@ -80,46 +80,10 @@ sections:\n       - question: |\n           How do I validate the CA configuration?\n         answer: |\n-          It's important to ensure that the CA configuration in the trust store results in Microsoft Entra being able to validate the CA trust chain. Also, it should successfully acquire the CRL from the configured CA CDP. To assist with this task, we recommend that you install the [MSIdentity Tools](https://aka.ms/msid) PowerShell module and run [`Test-MsIdCBATrustStoreConfiguration`](https://github.com/AzureAD/MSIdentityTools/wiki/Test-MsIdCBATrustStoreConfiguration).\n-\n-          The PowerShell cmdlet reviews the Microsoft Entra tenant CA configuration and surfaces errors and warnings for common configuration issues. \n-          \n-      - question: |\n-          How do I turn on certificate revocation checking for a specific CA?\n-        answer: |\n-          We highly recommend that you don't turn off CRL checking. If you turn off CRL checking, you can't revoke certificates.\n-\n-          However, if you need to investigate issues with CRL checking, you can exempt a CA from CRL checking in the Microsoft Entra admin center.\n-\n-          In the CBA authentication methods policy, select **Configure** > **Add exemption**. Select the CA that you want to exempt, and then select **Add**. \n-          \n-      - question: |\n-          Do CRLs have a size limit?\n-        answer: |\n-          The following CRL size limits apply: \n-\n-           - Interactive sign-in download limit: 20 MB for Azure Global (includes Azure Government Community Cloud), 45 MB for Azure for US Government (includes Azure Government Community Cloud High, Department of Defense)\n-           - Service download limit: 65 MB for Azure Global (includes Azure Government Community Cloud), 150 MB for Azure for US Government (includes Azure Government Community Cloud High, Department of Defense)\n-\n-            When a CRL download fails, the following message appears: \n-            \n-            \"The Certificate Revocation List (CRL) downloaded from \\<URI\\> has exceeded the maximum allowed size (\\<size\\> bytes) for CRLs in Microsoft Entra ID. If the issue persists, contact your tenant administrators.\"\n-            \n-            The download remains in the background, with higher limits.\n-\n-            We're reviewing the effect of these limits.\n-\n-      - question: |\n-          I see a valid CRL endpoint set, but why don't I see any CRL revocation?\n-        answer: |\n-          - Make sure that the CRL distribution point is set to a valid HTTP URL.\n-          - Make sure that the CRL distribution point is accessible via an internet-facing URL.\n-          - Make sure that the CRL sizes are within limits. \n-\n-      - question: |\n-          How do I instantly revoke a certificate?\n-        answer: |\n-          Complete the steps to [manually revoke a certificate](./certificate-based-authentication-federation-get-started.md#step-3-configure-revocation). \n+          It's important to ensure that the Certificate Authority configuration in the trust store results in Microsoft Entra's ability to both validate the certificate authority trust chain. Additionally, it should successfully acquire the certificate \n+          revocation list (CRL) from the configured certificate authority CRL distribution point (CDP). To assist with this task, it's recommended to install the \n+          [MSIdentity Tools](https://aka.ms/msid) PowerShell module and run [Test-MsIdCBATrustStoreConfiguration](https://github.com/AzureAD/MSIdentityTools/wiki/Test-MsIdCBATrustStoreConfiguration). \n+          This PowerShell cmdlet will review the Microsoft Entra tenant certificate authority configuration and surface errors/warnings for common mis-configuration issues. \n \n       - question: |\n           Do changes to the authentication methods policy take effect immediately?\n@@ -159,13 +123,7 @@ sections:\n \n            ```http\n            GET  https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/users?$filter=certificateUserIds/any(x:x eq 'bob@contoso.com')\n-           ```\n-\n-      - question: |\n-           After a CRL endpoint is configured, users can't sign in. They see the message \"AADSTS500173: Unable to download CRL. Invalid status code Forbidden from CRL distribution point. errorCode: 500173.\"\n-           \n-        answer: |\n-          This error commonly is seen when a firewall rule setting blocks access to the CRL endpoint. \n+           ```   \n \n       - question: |\n            Can Microsoft Entra CBA be used on Microsoft Surface Hub?"

    "sha": "4b9f1a3654ff14730c15aa38e4e1fb2875332ad5",
    "filename": "docs/identity/authentication/concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md",
    "status": "added",
